text: From 1906 to 1926, the Finnish Swimming Federation did not arrange a dedicated national competition, but spread out the hosting duties of the championship events to multiple clubs. == Diving == === Men === ==== Plain ==== Competed in Helsinki on 2 September 1906. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Rank ! Name ! Score |- | |align=left| Bernhard Fredriksson | 115.5 points |- | |align=left| Rudolf Eriksson | 108.5 points |- | |align=left| W. Sundman | 107.5 points |- | 4 |align=left| Toivo Aro | 107.0 points |- | 5 |align=left| Bruno Rosenbröijer | 106.5 points |- | 6 |align=left| Gunnar Ahlblad | 103.5 points |- | 7 |align=left| Artur Wetzell | 103.0 points |- | 8 |align=left| Oskar Wetzell | 89.5 points |- | 9 |align=left| E. Martikainen | 88.0 points |} Source: === Women === ==== Platform ==== Competed in Helsinki on 2 September 1906. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Rank ! Name ! Score |- | |align=left| Valborg Florström | 101.5 points |- | |align=left| Maria Henell | 97.5 points |} Source: == Swimming == === Men === ==== 100 metre freestyle ==== Competed in Vaasa on 28 July 1906. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Jääskeläinen | 1:31.5 |- | 7 |align=left| J. Malmivaara | 1:32.7 |- | 8 |align=left| Hugo Jonsson | 1:32.8 |- | 9 |align=left| L. Kemiläinen | 1:33.3 |- | 10 |align=left| Y. Time |- | |align=left| Herman Cederberg | 17:54.6 NR |- | |align=left| Aimo Malmberg | 19:21.8 |- | |align=left| Hugo Jonsson | 19:34.2 |- | 4 |align=left| J. Name ! Time |- | |align=left| Herman Cederberg | 3:06.8 NR |- | |align=left| Aimo Malmberg | 3:16.9 |- | |align=left| Hugo Jonsson | 3:24.5 |- | 4 |align=left| A. Lindholm | 3:26.7 |- | 5 |align=left| J. Malmivaara | 3:29.1 |- | 6 |align=left| Gunnar Ahlblad | 3:31.0 |- | 7 |align=left| John Henriksson | 3:31.6 |- | 8 |align=left| Eino Karjalainen | 3:37.8 |- | 9 |align=left| Arvid Rydman | 3:39.0 |- | 10 |align=left| Y. Andersson | 3:41.1 |- | 11 |align=left| A. Kemppainen | 3:44.6 |- | 12 |align=left| K. Aaltonen | 3:49.2 |- | 13 |align=left| Väinö Siro | 3:51.0 |} Source: Cederberg's time would have been the world record later when FINA was founded, but they refused to ratify it because he wore swimming briefs instead of a racing suit. === Women === ==== 100 metre freestyle ==== Competed in Helsinki on 22 July 1906. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Rank ! Name ! Time |- | |align=left| Elsa Lingonblad | 1:51.4 NR |- | |align=left| Anna Björkman | 1:51.4 |- | |align=left| Elin Westerberg | 2:03.4 |- | 4 |align=left| Dagmar Kneckt | 2:08.7 |} Source: Elsa Lingonblad became the first to win an official Finnish championship in aquatics. == Sources == * === References === Category:National swimming competitions Category:National championships in Finland Category:Swimming competitions in Finland Category:1906 in Finnish sport Category:1906 in aquatics Category:Diving competitions in Finland
title: 1906 Finnish championships in aquatics
